Award.AwardTitle: Advancing Female Faculty: Institutional climate, Retention and Mentoring (AFFIRM)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The University of San Diego is a primarily undergraduate institution that proposes a variety of activities designed to recruit and retain women STEM faculty with a particular focus on women of color. The first primary goal of this project is to improve the climate through a climate survey and interactive role playing presentations. The second primary goal is to improve recruitment through the development of toolkits, trainings, cross-cultural competency workshops, and policy change. The third goal of improved retention and advancement is pursued through workshops on work/life balance, tenure and promotion, and professional writing as well as a mentoring program and a distinguished URM women scientist lecture series. All programming has a unique and well informed focus on women of color.

INTELLECTUAL MERIT

The intellectual merit of this proposal lies in its firm grounding in the social science literature, especially the literature about women of color in the academy. Their cluster of proposed activities is likely to positively impact the women on the USD campus and stands to serve as a model for increasing the representation of STEM women of color across the country.

BROADER IMPACTS

Problems with the recruitment and retention of women-of-color STEM faculty plague the academy and weaken the scientific workforce. This multi-faceted project provides a roadmap to alleviate the problem in smaller, less research-intensive institutions. Their evaluation and dissemination plans are well conceived which contributes to the likelihood that they will be able to make a significant contribution to the literature.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our project entitled AFFIRM (Advancement of Female Faculty: Institutional climate, Recruitment and Mentoring) had three goals: 1) To foster an environment that understands, embraces and supports a diverse faculty; 2) To recruit women faculty, with a particular emphasis on women of color and 3) To support the retention and advancement of female faculty. These goals were met over the grant period by initially administering a climate survey and conducting focus groups to assess the current campus climate with respect to diversity, inclusion and advancement of faculty. This information informed the design of a campus-wide mentoring program to help pre-tenure faculty navigate the institution and their position within an academic department and to nurture their scholarly engagement. An interactive theatre skit was developed to highlight some of the issues that emerge as faculty, particularly women and faculty of color are evaluated by their peers. This skit was presented in the context of a workshop for departmental chairs as well as other faculty and encouraged conversations about objectivity and fairness in hiring and promotion. In addition, the grant team hosted a Distinguished Visiting Professor annually for a two-day visit. These women presented their work/life story in a public lecture, conduct workshops and met with administrators, faculty and students.

In the Fall of 2014 the University of San Diego welcomed a seven-member cohort of women faculty (the AFFIRM Faculty Cohort) to 5 STEM departments on campus. This unique hire included women of color and became one of our signature efforts. The success of these talented women and their contributions to the University encouraged us to develop this as a model for future faculty hiring efforts.
